RT @EnvAgencyNW: Our Cheshire Field Team have been clearing out this watercourse on Sealand Road #Chester. Keeping watercourses free from b‚Ä¶
@Newscooch @EnvAgencyMids @EnvAgency I have just been reading into riparian land restoration. 100% agree.
@EnvAgencyMids Why did you do this?
@NickMott7 @olds_liam @EnvAgencyMids @EnvAgency @EAGeomorphology @BiodiversityEA @WildTroutTrust @theriverstrust I don't understand why they did that?

@N_Rivers_Trust @ShamsGalib @EnvAgencyAnglia @GlavenEel @banhamzoo @WildTroutTrust @Eleri_Pritchard @Dan_Chadwick1 @DrCrayfish I doubt that carrying crayfish eggs is the issue here - I doubt eggs survive when separated from the female-they are physically attached. Biggest problem is the transport of young - here's one of my images that shows fully formed juveniles which will soon be released to the wild. https://t.co/oEJrPOwHuC

text: Great, but when we see this in lots of places other than nature reserves I'll be very happy. But well done to @LeicsWildlife and @EnvAgencyMids nonetheless. https://t.co/2x2CLRPkIU

@GlavenEel @N_Rivers_Trust @stuartpengs @ShamsGalib @EnvAgencyAnglia @banhamzoo @WildTroutTrust @Eleri_Pritchard @Dan_Chadwick1 @DrCrayfish There, too!? Had no idea! Brought in for fur there, too? Yes, being an island certainly has benefits! Invasives are everywhere here: starlings, pythons, lionfish in the Gulf of Mexico, etc. And feral cats, a sensitive topic.

@NOLALeyda @N_Rivers_Trust @stuartpengs @ShamsGalib @EnvAgencyAnglia @banhamzoo @WildTroutTrust @Eleri_Pritchard @Dan_Chadwick1 @DrCrayfish Oh, I didn't realise nutrias were a problem there too!Thankfully somehow we have managed to eradicate them here but we're a tiny island compared to you guys.
RT @Edwards8: @CRTvolunteers @HighwaysSEAST @WalAbbeyNews @murrayscott06 @Habgas @thisisyourriver @EnvAgency Here we go again, fly tipping‚Ä¶

Great to deliver this @SouthWestWater funded project with them, the @EnvAgencySW, #BrooklandsAggregates #JWBaronEartworks plus Prof. David Gilvear, from @PlymUni who has monitored the particle distribution for 5 years with MSc students #BringingRiversToLife 3/3 https://t.co/jHXHHZs4DS

Users can now investigate a wider range of scenario uncertainty with an update to the #UKCP18 Global (60 km) climate model simulations to include a low emissions scenario (RCP 2.6). Find out moreüëâhttps://t.co/g33qGh923c 

@beisgovuk @DefraGovUK @EnvAgency https://t.co/5BOQTAzf0P

@GlavenEel @N_Rivers_Trust @stuartpengs @ShamsGalib @EnvAgencyAnglia @banhamzoo @WildTroutTrust @Eleri_Pritchard @Dan_Chadwick1 @DrCrayfish Nonatives can be devastating. Here we have a problem nutria rats, introduced for their fur many decades ago. Now they destroy crucial banks and water plants. State pays people for pelts, but still a big problem. 

I fret about ocean farmed salmon, other fish. :-(

text: This is the guy behind the company that had the huge waste fire in County Durham last month. 5,000t estimated to have burned. @EnvAgency #stillworkin https://t.co/tVxKljFlf8

@NOLALeyda @N_Rivers_Trust @stuartpengs @ShamsGalib @EnvAgencyAnglia @banhamzoo @WildTroutTrust @Eleri_Pritchard @Dan_Chadwick1 @DrCrayfish They have also decimated our river banks by burrowing, causing siltation,as well as eating fish eggs,fry and reducing the quality of habitat for fish and invertebrates.People still keep spreading them illegally. We live in constant fear of losing our native crays :( 2/2

@NOLALeyda @N_Rivers_Trust @stuartpengs @ShamsGalib @EnvAgencyAnglia @banhamzoo @WildTroutTrust @Eleri_Pritchard @Dan_Chadwick1 @DrCrayfish Yes, red swamp and signal craws are also farmed here and were released as a food source. Nobody realised the absolute devastation they would cause on our rivers and native species. They have wiped out most of our native crayfish which have no immunity to crayfish plague. 1/2
@EnvAgencyNW @EnvAgency @greennuneaton this is right up your street.
RT @EnvAgencyNW: Are you new to #NaturalFloodManagement and funding? If so, then we need your help. We‚Äôre working on a project to make it e‚Ä¶

@GlavenEel @N_Rivers_Trust @stuartpengs @ShamsGalib @EnvAgencyAnglia @banhamzoo @WildTroutTrust @Eleri_Pritchard @Dan_Chadwick1 @DrCrayfish Thanks. Here in south Louisiana, people catch, and even farm, crawfish. I didn‚Äôt know you guys had any native ones there! Plague would be disaster down here.

urls.title: The shocking state of our rivers: Whose story are we telling?
urls.description: Written on 22 September 2020. Last week, England‚Äôs Environment Agency (EA) released the results from their latest assessment of the health of our rivers. They look pretty dismal. But are these data really telling the full story? According to the assessment, only 14% of rivers are considered to be of ‚Äògood ecological status‚Äô. This is a combined measurement of the quality of their basic water quality (for example; nutrient concentrations and pH); the condition of the habitats they provide; and the species

text: @NOLALeyda @N_Rivers_Trust @stuartpengs @ShamsGalib @EnvAgencyAnglia @banhamzoo @WildTroutTrust @Eleri_Pritchard @Dan_Chadwick1 @DrCrayfish No, it is very bad practice to remove them from site. You risk carrying crayfish plague to other locations which wipes out our native crayfish. You must have a permit to trap and move them to a licensed location for consumption.

@OJS50 @N_Rivers_Trust @stuartpengs @ShamsGalib @EnvAgencyAnglia @banhamzoo @WildTroutTrust @Eleri_Pritchard @Dan_Chadwick1 @DrCrayfish Trapping crayfish is illegal without a permit. It is dangerous for other species like otters and watervole and is also counterproductive to control crayfish. It also carries a high risk of spreading crayfish eggs and crayfish plague. Trapping should be banned outright.
